forecast.review: My initial forecast of 75% was too high and exhibited overconfidence based on the status quo. I was overly swayed by Aaron Judge's current .414 average and the short, 13-day timeframe, underestimating the powerful effect of regression to the mean and the inherent volatility of batting averages. Both Forecaster 2 (30%) and Forecaster 3 (40%) presented compelling arguments centered on this statistical principle. Their reasoning that even a mild, common slump could quickly pull Judge's average below the .400 threshold was particularly convincing. I had calculated that Judge needed to hit approximately .354 over the remaining period, but I failed to properly appreciate how difficult and statistically unlikely even that is, especially for a player already on a prolonged hot streak. Their emphasis on the fragility of the average—how a single hitless game or two can cause a significant drop—was a key point I had not weighted heavily enough. While I still believe Judge's demonstrated ability over the past two months warrants a significant probability, the other forecasters correctly identified that the statistical and historical precedents make a 'No' outcome more likely.
forecast.rationale:
After reviewing the other forecasts, I am significantly lowering my probability. My initial forecast of 75% was an overreaction to the current data point of Aaron Judge's .414 average. The other panelists correctly highlighted the powerful and statistically robust principle of regression to the mean. It is far more likely that Judge's performance over the next two weeks will be closer to his elite-but-not-historic career norms than it is that he will continue to perform at a .400+ pace.

The key insight I've incorporated is the fragility of the batting average. A short slump, such as going 3-for-16 over a four-game stretch—a common occurrence for any player—would likely drop his average below .400. The probability of him avoiding any such mini-slump for another thirteen days is much lower than I first estimated.

Therefore, I am inverting my forecast to make 'No' the more likely outcome. However, I am not going as low as 30% or 40%. The fact that Judge has sustained this elite performance for nearly two months is strong evidence of his current form, and the remaining timeframe is very short. This provides a substantial chance he can carry the streak through to the resolution date. I am revising my forecast to 45%, reflecting that while a 'No' vote is the statistically sounder position due to regression, the specific circumstances create a very plausible path to 'Yes'. This represents a 30-point decrease from my initial forecast, driven entirely by the strength of the other forecasters' reasoning.
